title: Inheritance of Manasseh
shortSummary: Joshua 17 details the allotment of land to the tribe of Manasseh, including the special case of Zelophehad's daughters who claim their inheritance. The chapter highlights the challenges the Israelites face in fully possessing the land due to remaining Canaanite inhabitants and emphasizes the call to faith and courage in driving them out.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Division of the Promised Land after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Manasseh
keyCharacters.description: The firstborn son of Joseph whose descendants receive a large portion of land, including territories east and west of the Jordan.

keyCharacters.name: Zelophehad's Daughters
keyCharacters.description: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah; they petition for and receive an inheritance despite having no brothers, setting a precedent for inheritance rights.

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who oversees the distribution of the land and encourages the tribe of Joseph to be strong and possess their inheritance.

keyCharacters.name: Eleazar the Priest
keyCharacters.description: The high priest who, along with Joshua and the tribal leaders, confirms the inheritance rights of Zelophehad's daughters.

definitions.definition: A portion of land assigned to each tribe by casting lots, symbolizing God's sovereign distribution of the Promised Land.
The land or property passed down to descendants, often signifying God's covenant promises to His people.
The original inhabitants of the land of Canaan, whom the Israelites were commanded to drive out to fully possess the land.
Military vehicles made of iron used by the Canaanites, representing formidable opposition to Israel's conquest.

outline.heading: Land Allotted to Manasseh and Zelophehad's Daughters
outline.description: The chapter opens with the division of land for the tribe of Manasseh, including the special case of Zelophehad's daughters who claim their rightful inheritance, demonstrating God's justice and provision.

outline.heading: Geographical Boundaries and Cities of Manasseh
outline.description: This section describes the specific borders and cities within Manasseh's territory, highlighting the extent of their inheritance and the complexity of tribal boundaries.

outline.heading: Challenges in Possessing the Land
outline.description: Despite receiving their inheritance, the tribe of Manasseh struggles to drive out the Canaanite inhabitants, who remain and become subjects paying tribute, illustrating incomplete obedience and ongoing spiritual battles.

outline.heading: Request for Additional Land and Joshua's Encouragement
outline.description: The descendants of Joseph request more land due to their large population; Joshua encourages them to be strong and take the forested hill country by force, trusting God's promise despite the enemy's strength.

application: Trust in God's provision and justice, as seen in the inheritance granted to Zelophehad's daughters, encouraging believers to seek God's will boldly and righteously.
Be courageous and proactive in claiming the spiritual 'inheritance' God has given, even when facing strong opposition or challenges.
Recognize the importance of obedience in fully possessing what God has promised, avoiding compromise with worldly influences that can hinder spiritual victory.
Encourage unity and faith within the community of believers, as Joshua did with the tribes of Joseph, to accomplish God's purposes together.

keyVerses.text: And they came near before Eleazar the priest, and before Joshua the son of Nun, and before the princes, saying, The LORD commanded Moses to give us an inheritance among our brethren. Therefore according to the commandment of the LORD he gave them an inheritance among the brethren of their father.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms God's faithfulness to His promises and the rightful inheritance of Zelophehad's daughters, highlighting God's justice and the importance of honoring His commands.

keyVerses.text: And the children of Joseph spake unto Joshua, saying, Why hast thou given me but one lot and one portion to inherit, seeing I am a great people, forasmuch as the LORD hath blessed me hitherto?
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the desire for growth and expansion under God's blessing, encouraging believers to recognize and steward the blessings God provides.

keyVerses.text: But the mountain shall be thine; for it is a wood, and thou shalt cut it down: and the outgoings of it shall be thine: for thou shalt drive out the Canaanites, though they have iron chariots, and though they be strong.
keyVerses.significance: This verse challenges believers to rely on God's power and courageously overcome obstacles, trusting that no enemy is too strong when God is with His people.
